I think the metal feels hotter because it conducts heat better, so it reaches the hand.

Theres a second point that infuences it. Cause if you touch a piece of lets say 100°C tin foil it wont feel as hot as touching 100°C brick although tin foil conducts heat bether than brick. Theres one other difference: the overall heat capacity. A big brick will have more energy at 100°C than a small piece of tin foil..And thus at the moment you touch the tin foil, it will be very soon as warm as your hand,but zhe brick will stay hot. Of course with big object this effect isnt that huge any more,but at the surface of the object it will matter. Imagane a substance with medium heat conductivity, but very very high heat capacity. If you touch it, it will feel very hot, and the surface wont get cold soon. So you will get burned. But now imagine a substance with medium heat conductivity, but very low heat capacity. This substance wont burn you, cause at the point you touched it, the surface will be cold very soon.
I think with air this gets important. If you have got just very slowly moving air (it moves only because of heat differences) Its heat conductivity is at a medium range (it can move freely, thus the heat conductivity isnt as low as it was, if it was enclosed in lets say styrofoam). But its heat capacity is low. So it wont burn you. But if you've got wet air, ots heat conductivity goes up,and also its heat capacity goes up. So it feels way hotter. If you only had high heat conductivity (wind), it wouldnt feel as hot, as it feels if the heat capacity( wet) is high. (you can touch the wind coming out of a hairdryer very fast, but dry, but you cant touch steam coming out of a boiling pressure pot of water.)

With nine hundred sixty-six comments already here when I arrive, I am guessing this has already been addressed, but just in case (and because I feel like being a picky bastard at the moment):

Everything expressed/concluded by Derek in this video seems to me to be correct if (and only if) we are discussing the bulk temperatures of the entire objects in question. However, I believe that because of the difference in thermal conductivity, the portion of the object in contact with the human hand would actually have a different temperature, because as soon as the human hand at 37°C comes into contact with the object at 15°C, heat will begin to flow from the hand to the object, and establish a temperature gradient in the object that cools with distance from the point of contact. The slope of the temperature gradient would be inversely related to the thermal conductivity of the object, with the result that at the points of contact, the low conductivity book would have a noticeably higher temperature than the hard drive. If both objects were at thermal equilibrium and then picked up at the same time, they would feel the same at the moment of first contact, but the temperatures at the contact points would rapidly diverge.

Even if Derek had stated clearly that he was talking only about the bulk average temperature of each object, there would still be a difference between the two after a period of human contact, but that difference would be related to the heat capacity of the objects, and I believe it would develop much more slowly. I don't know anything about the heat capacity of paper or the bulk heat capacity of a hard drive (which would of course contain some dead air to complicate things) so I won't wager a guess as to which would actually be warmer, but I expect there would be a small difference there as well!

I have no complaints about the results of the cake versus tin experiment, though. I'm sure a temperature difference would develop due to differences in exposed surface area and the different contact materials (stove top vs. ambient air) but in terms of what was being measured and discussed, I would conclude that these differences would be irrelevant. :-)

So like the slippery ice video, the science here is not quite right.  Two different materials exposed to heat for the same amount of time do not necessarily reach the same temperature.  Materials have two major properties that affect their respective temperature:  The colour of the material decided the amount of heat reflected or absorbed and the properties of the material also decide on the amount of heat absorbed (and retained).  The best example of this is metal vs ceramic.  But at the extreme temperatures we can more easily deduce the differences ie: At, say, 700 degrees c some metals will have melted into liquid where ceramic will still be intact.  In fact if you notice when he first measured the temperature of the cake as it came out of the oven, he did in fact get 2 significant different temperatures and then he went on to re-measure the temperature as the metal more quickly re-radiated its heat (cooled down quicker) than  the cake and at a certain moment they had about the same temperature.  He should have continued capturing temperatures and logging the temperatures and one would very easily see that  metal would continue to cool down faster than the cake.

Hey Derek, the cake and the tin are NOT the same temperature, for an entirely different reason than what you're demonstrating. The cake has water in it, so it can't heat above 100℃. All the water would have to turn into steam first. The surface can be slightly hotter because it's dry, but the close contact with the inside still keeps it around that point. Metal cookware has no such limitations. The reason your readings were so close is because you measured the surface of the cake and a part of the tin that was in direct contact with – and therefore cooled by – the cake. Had you measured the inside of the cake with a Thermapen for example, it would've been below or at 100℃. More importantly, measuring a part of the tin that's not in contact with the cake, such as a handle, could possibly have resulted in a much higher reading, up to the oven's set temperature. I respect your work tremendously and learned a lot from your videos, but I don't think this particular demonstration proves your point very well!

Incidentally, this is why outer space doesn't actually feel that cold. Since it is a vacuum, it can't conduct heat from your body. You will still lose heat through radiation, but it is a much slower process for our bodies. So the actual sensation of the 'temperature' of space would be quite pleasant when the sun is eclipsed behind the Earth (of course, the sensation of having all of the gases in your bodies forcibly expelled from all of your orifices at once and then blacking out from shock and asphyxiation will be decidedly less pleasant). If you were to somehow remain conscious but exposed to the vacuum of space, it would over time start to feel quite cold as you lose more and more heat. But it's far from the 'instafreeze' environment it's depicted in various media.

But speaking of the sun, this is where it really starts to defy expectation. In space, you face the full, unfiltered radiation of the sun. The sensation of the sunlight without any cooler ambient temperature would feel akin to the sensation of sunlight in the Sahara desert (an extremely dry environment), plus unfiltered radiation in the ultraviolet spectrum will make the sensation even hotter and the dangers of sunburn far more immediately dangerous. In fact, the primary heat-related issue that had to be addressed for astronaut suits wasn't just keeping them warm in the coldness of space, but keeping them cool in the heat of the unfiltered sun.

This applies to things like the space station and probes as well. Their electronics and processes create heat, which sometimes cannot be radiated out into the vacuum of space faster than the heat is being generated. This is referred to as "waste heat" (it applies to normal machinery here on Earth as well, but it's bigger problem in space due to the heat conduction issue) and is another consideration in designing vehicles, machinery, and electronics in space.

Here's what I think. In a bid to create a natural balance we are either feeling heat entering our bodies when the object is warmer than we are, or we feel the heat leaving our bodies when the object is colder than we are. Please disregard the other answer you received; it is wrong. First, your question should look more like this, “if something is 0K, does it still have thermal energy?” because heat is the movement of thermal energy. It’s a process, not something a material can have. Something with a temperature of 0K would have no thermal energy, so all heat would be into it. (heat = flow of thermal energy) Further debunking the other response, heat is not just a wave of radiation.
Cont.

That is only one type of heat, radiant heat. There’s also conduction and convection. Radiant heat needs no medium to travel though. If it did, we wouldn’t receive any energy from the sun. The other two types do require a medium to work. This is why there is a layer of vacuum in thermoses, to minimize loss of thermal energy. Also, 0K is impossible because of the laws of thermodynamics.
tl;dr Something at 0K has no thermal energy, so energy flows towards it (in the process known as heat).

There is one question that still bothers me to this day.  How is it possible to maintain a body temperature of 37 C, in a humid tropical background of 40 C?

Sweating would be the obvious answer, for somewhere dry like Egypt.  But what about somewhere hot and muggy like Thailand?

Another interesting question to ponder, is why does a 37 C environment feel uncomfortably hot, when you'd think that would be the neutral temperature for humans?

The answer is that our heater is still burning inside.  We have a requisite heat to reject, and we'd need to reject that requisite spot-on to the slightly colder background in order to feel neutral.

Think about fluorescent tubes (those big long light bulbs). They have a temperature of around 3773C, or, 6823F.  That is HOT!!!  Glass melts around 1600C. @Dixavd the experience of hot or cold is subjective to each person but it depends on the rate at which your body is losing or gaining heat to the environment. If it is losing heat very quickly, it will feel cold. If it is losing heat very slowly, and/or receiving heat from its environment, it will feel warm. and this is all relative to your body's ability to replenish lost heat and rid itself of excess heat.

Paper is a poor heat conductor, but a pretty good heat conserving material.
Metal is a very good heat conductor,but poor at conserving heat.
So when you touch paper you feel your own body temperature build up on the touch point iow it feels warm.
But when you touch metal,
it provides a heat conductor between air 21° and your hand skin 35°,
and because contact area with air is bigger than with your skin,
your hand cools down fast, iow it feels cold.
